ewcount\count \edef	est{\count=1} \showthe\count will show 0, not 1, because, again, none of \count=1 were expandable. one can imagine a system where such operations are expandable. more precisely, expanding \def would absorb a control sequence name, parameter text and replacement text from the  has_external_tag  stream, define the new macro and expand to nothing. similarly, an operation named \assign would read a register name and a value from the  has_external_tag , do the assignment and expand to nothing. this can be also extended to \let, \advance etc. thus the above  has_external_tag  would now behave d has_external_tag ferently: in the first \edef, \def would read in \a{x}, define \a and expand to empty text. after this  has_external_tag  the token list would contain \a, which would then expand to x. in the second example (let it be \edef	est{\assign\count1} now) \assign would set \count to 1, and expand to nothing. in the result 	est would be defined to be empty, but the value of \count would have been altered. this new system would allow to achieve some things in a more straightward manner. for example, the problem of defining a macro expanding to n asterisks could now be solved with 
ewcount\c \def\asterisks#1{% \assign\c0 \loop\ has_external_tag num\c<#1 *% \advance\c by 1 epeat} , because (see the definitions of \loop and \iterate) \def, \let and assignments are now expandable. another substantial consequence would be that many more things could be done in  has_external_tag  whose result is passed as an argument to another macro. observe how  has_external_tag 's
